user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.14 is: The Standard Library function memcmp shall not be used to compare null terminated strings.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of unescape_wrapper:
```c
static size_t
unescape_wrapper (void *cls,
                  struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                  char *val)
{
  bool broken;
  size_t res;
  (void) cls; /* Mute compiler warning. */

  /* TODO: add individual parameter */
  if (0 <= connection->daemon->client_discipline)
    return MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_strict_ (val);

  res = MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (val, &broken);
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  if (broken)
  {
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("The URL encoding is broken.\n"));
  }
#endif /* HAVE_MESSAGES */
  return res;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
res = MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ (val, &broken);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.14 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the fragment calls MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_(val, &broken) and does not call memcmp or otherwise compare null-terminated strings in the shown code. Therefore Rule 21.14 is not violated by this fragment. (Note: if the implementation of MHD_str_pct_decode_in_place_lenient_ internally used memcmp to compare null-terminated strings, that internal code would need review, but that is outside the scope of the shown fragment.)
